pronunciation: MOR'TIFY, [Latin mors, death, and facio, to make.]

definitions.text:
Mortify
 [Latin mors, death, and facio, to make.]
1. To destroy the organic texture and vital functions of some part of a living animal; to change to sphacelus gangrene. Extreme inflammation speedily mortifies flesh.
2. To subdue bring into subjection, as the bodily appetites by abstinence rigorous severities. We mortify ourselves with fish. With fasting mortified, worn out with tears.
3. To subdue; to abase; to humble; to reduce; to restrain; as inordinate passions. thy learned lust. therefore your members which are upon the earth. Colossians 3:5.
4. To humble; to depress; to affect with slight vexation. How often is the ambitious man mortified with the very praises he receives, they do not rise so high as he thinks they ought. He is controlled by a nod, mortified by a frown, and transported with a smile.
5. To destroy active powers essential qualities. He mortified pearls in vinegar--Quicksilver--mortified with turpentine.[I believe this application is not now in use.]

To lose vital heat and action and suffer the dissolution of organic texture, as flesh; to corrupt gangrene.
1. To be subdued.
2. To practice severities and penance from religious motives. This makes him give alms of all that he hath, watch, fast and mortify
